position.marginalia_text: In expeditissimis, et efficacissimis paragraphis Pandectarum, totius Juris Romani selectiss[im]is { Gemmis: Eccè omnes prudentissima[e], et acutissima[e] Sententia[e] Pragmatica[e], omniu[m] excellentissimorum Jurisconsultorum: certè summa a[e]stimatione dignissima[e]: et pra[e]gnatisssimi Fontes Justitia[e] forensis: quicquid nugentur Ciuilium Actionum imperiti Grammatici, et Philologi. Desinant igitur Noui homines, contra fo[e]licissimu[m] Justinianu[m], et certè prudentissimu[m] Tribonianum queri, de Veteru[m] Jurisconsultoru[m] Romanorum iactura: quorum hîc existant omnes, aut quasi omnes pra[e]gnantissima[e] Sententia[e] forenses. Nam sicui facta est Iniuria, illis est solis inflicta Veteribus Iurisconsultis, qui immortalem gloriam sperabant è suis commentarijs: non aut ipsi Jurisprudentia[e], qua[e] in pressiorem, certioremq[ue] redacta est Artis formulam: aut suis, nostris'ue posteris, nouis Legu[m] professoribus; qui habent paucis plurima; eaq[ue] certè, et solidè perstricta, qua[e] priùs videbantur nimiu[m] vaga, et infinita. Sint literati homines in sua classe, qui Ciuilem Triboniani Industriam satis inciuili temeritate accusant: sed su[n]t in aliena Rep[ublica] nimiùm curiosi, et vltra crepidam no[n] sapiu[n]t nimis. Suidas, vt alijs quibusdam, sic Justiniano, et Triboniano, apertè iniquuus: Valla, merus Gram[m]aticus, et logoda[e]dalus, in alienas philosophia[e], Jurisq[ue], messes temerè irrumpens: Viues, in multis nimiùm similis Valla[e]: Antonius Nebrissensis, ieiunus in Jure Lexicographus; nec Legu[m] peritior, quà[m] Accursius [verborum:]

marginalia.translation: In the expeditious and efficacious paragraphs of the 'Digest' are the most precious jewels of Roman law. Here are all the wisest, most acute statements of pragmatism that have been made by all the best lawyers. Certainly, the statements are the most worthy of the highest praise and the lawyers are the most pregnant sources of public justice, whatever nonsense ignorant grammaticians and philologians may spout about civil suits. If only the 'new men' would stop complaining about worthy Justinian and wise Tribonianus, about the writings of the old Roman lawyers that they are prepared to throw away. Here are all - or almost all - of their most pregnant public statements. For if wrong has been done to anyone, it has been inflicted only on those old lawyers, who were hoping for immortal glory from their commentaries. And neither to the jurisprudence, which has been skillfully edited into a more concise and more settled shape, nor to their, our, or future new teachers of law, who have gained the most things by the least effort, and those things certainly and solidly compressed, which previously seemed vague and boundless in the extreme. There may be intellectual types of the kind to accuse the civil industry of Tribonianus of plenty of incivil temerity. But they are too curious about a foreign republic and know nothing more than the soles of their feet. Suda: obviously unfair to others, such as Justinian and Tribonianus. Valla: a mere grammatician and logodaedalus, blundering into the foreign fields of philosophy and law. Vives: in many ways too similar to Valla. Antonio de Nebrija: a naive legal lexicographer and not more skillful in laws than Accursius is [in words].
